metadata.title: Psychoanalytic Quarterly, LXXII, 2003 COMMENTARY ON ILANY KOGAN'S liON BEING A DEAD, BELOVED CHILD"

body_text.text: In a paper entitled "World Beyond Metaphor" (1982) , published in Generations of the Holocaust, I first tried to posit mechanisms for the transmission of historical trauma from the primarily affected generation to its progeny, and then to explore the ways in which the formation of the mind of the child of survivors might itself be affected by direct interaction with the survivor parents. My technique involved juxtaposing psychoanalytic material from a survivor's son with that from a survivor mother, and extrapolating how pain in the mother might be conveyed to the son, resulting in altered mental processes that reflected the mother's suffering.

This work preceded much knowledge that has since accrued about the ways in which traumatic experience changes brain structure and function and the ways in which the attachment experiences of children of survivors may reflect these neurobiological transformations. We now have access to Hesse and Main's (2000) important work on disorganized attachment and the ways in which traumatized caregivers transmit in their linguistic discourse unsettling and structure-altering directives, inferences, and problematic relational data that take up residence in the minds and behavior of their offspring.

In that early paper and subsequently, I have used the psychoanalytic perspective, one in which individual meaning is accessed in a two-person setting where the relationship between analyst and analysand-fraught as it is with both possibility and limitconstitutes the Spielraum, play space, in which meaning is construe-ted and an affectively true narrative created. This approach recognizes the essential reconfiguring and recontextualizing attributes of all mnemonic processes and the dual possibility that traumatic intrusions will constrict the play space, with traumatic foreclosures and freezings of the metaphoric process being contributed by either participant. All psychoanalysis potentially suffers from the imposition of an inflexible metaphor from the analyst, reflecting his or her theoretical orientation; all analysis needs to deal with the playful potentials and constrictions that the analysand's experience, cognitive style, and self/theoretical orientation convey. When analyst and analysand are inclined to favor overlapping metaphoric pruning for either similarly traumatically tutored or similarly theoretically tutored Anlagen, then the analytic play space is maximally constricted, and the possibilities of the analysand's learning about him-or herself and ways of processing meaning are similarly ceilinged.
In his latest substantial contribution to the analytic literature, Imagination and the Meaningful Brain (2003), Modell writes:

Clinical observation leads to the unmistakable conclusion that psychological trauma may result in a failure to recategorize or recontextualize memory. The inability to recontextualize memory determines whether a given experience will prove to be traumatic. As we have different methods at our disposal with which to recategorize memory, individuals will react to trauma in their own particular way, so the effect of a given environmental trauma is variable and unpredictable. When there is an inability to recontextualize memory, the experience of the present, the here and now, will be pervaded by memories of the past. In this fashion, trauma will constrict the complexity of consciousness. The process of the retrieval of traumatic memories gives further support to the hypothesis that an unconscious metaphoric process is operative in the waking state. As the critic and novelist Cynthia Ozick writes, "Metaphor [like the Delphic Oracle] is also a priest of interpretation, but what it interprets is memory" (1991) . When metaphor is the interpreter of traumatic memories, it interprets with the aid of metonymy (a part substituting for the whole) and metaphoric memorial categories are evoked by metonymic associations. But trauma can be self-sustaining, as trauma will degrade the metaphoric process; here the metaphoric process transfers meaning from the past to the present without transformation, and as a consequence, imagination is constricted. The past becomes a template for the present, creating a loss of ambiguity in the experience of the here and now; there is an absence of the customary play of similarity and difference. In experiential terms, this means that the present is conflated with the past. [pp. 38-39, italics in original] The neurolinguistic-affective notion of metaphoric fluidity employed by Modell, with its attendant capacities to recontextualize and recategorize memory, corresponds, I believe, to what might be called playing with "full-deck" capacity (Herzog and O'Connell, unpublished) -the emphasis on the play and its deformation after trauma reflecting my work as a child and adult analyst, and constituting a phenomenological description of what Modell set out to describe in terms of cognitive process and neuropsychological underpinnings. I have described the ways in which, in the presence of traumatic stimulation (both direct and transmitted), the play function shifts to the left (a model borrowed from hematology): from displacement to enactment to interactive enactment. * * * * * * * * Ilany Kogan, in her characteristically creative, careful, and compassionate analytic work, shows us how she and her patient Nurit identified foreclosed and frozen metaphors and reconstructed a narrative that sought to explain seemingly varied libidinal, aggressive, and narcissistic availability and the patient's mother's capacity to recognize Nurit for herself. The analyst is careful to identify the ways in which an analytically useful transferential repetition could be tolerated and recognized by both parties, as well as the constraining variables that obtained in both the transference and countertransference. She also cogently details the way in which aggression as a forbidden and Nazi-identified modality was proscribed from the treatment as a form of interactive enactment (play in which the analyst has to be a particular way) and the process by which it found its way back into the analytic play.

I hope to offer a few thoughts as a respectful and adjunctive complement to Ms. Kogan's awesome and moving analytic experience with Nurit. In her work, she focuses on the ways in which being a replacement child burden her patient's development, and on putative mechanisms by which the patient's mother was able to both initially compensate for her terrible trauma by a kind of supernormal development, and then to subject Nurit to persecutory rage and attack, in response to which she needed to adumbrate both obsessive-compulsive symptoms and an internal distortion of her own aggression and self sense. Ms. Kogan also notes the father's incapacity to protect his daughter and thus to buffer or titrate the toxicity of the maternal onslaught.

To the analyst's thoughtful and persuasive formulations, I wish to append and discuss another aspect of transmitted and directly inflicted trauma, which I and others have noted in the analyses of children of survivors. This is the relationship of distortions in the patient's and the analyst's relation to aggression in the treatment, and in turn, its relationship to the impaired role of paternal functioning, both historically and in the here and now. I shall discuss this concept with regard to Nurit and to a patient of mine, Dr. B.

I have already mentioned that Nurit's father was not able to buffer her from the blitzkrieg-like assault launched by her mother. It seems to me that on a multigenerational scale, the paternal presence was vitiated. During the mother's young adulthood, the men all left, responding to the belief that the Nazis threatened primarily them and would not endanger the remaining women and children. It was in this context that the initial aktion took place and the first daughter was lost. Nor was there paternal protection when the maternal aktion was directed toward Nurit.

Paternal presence, when endorsed by maternal holding and regard for the father, provides a child with multifocal experience in the nature of aggressive modulation and organization. It also provides intrapsychic practice in gear shifting and the accommodative mode. To put it another way, paternal "disruptive attunement" in the presence of maternal "homeostatic attunement" helps to nurture and shape these important capacities (E. W. Herzog and J. M. Herzog 1982; J. M. Herzog 2001) . The father plays with his child by asking the child to match him, whereas the mother usually matches the child. This need to gauge and take the measure of the other, as well as to manage the upset and intrusion of another's agenda, is of vital importance to the child, resulting in growth-promoting alterations in brain capacities and behavioral possibilities. As such, it helps the child to "roll with the punches" and is protective against traumatic incursions and subsequent deformation.

The transgenerational absence of paternal functioning is a part of Nurit's dilemma and, I believe, figures into the transference and countertransference issues with the mobilization of modulated aggression as a necessary component of the self, intrapsychically and interactively. The Spielraum has been rendered maleless, fatherless, and coupleless, both historically and then in the repetition, and this is the background against which Nurit must struggle to understand herself, her mother, and their interaction. In the absence of a playful and protective father and a strong parentogenic alliance, she can neither resist the maternal incursion nor mobilize her own aggression on her behalf. * * * * * * * * To further develop this point, let me tell you about Dr. B, a 59-year-old physicist in analysis, as he recounts an experience he had in Singapore. He has attended a conference there and made an important presentation. He has been excited about this trip, talking before his departure about the pros and cons of the justice system in this city-state, with special reference to the crimes and punishments of the American boy Michael Fay. He has been thoroughly engaged with this issue as a forum for discussing out-of-control boys and external consequence as providing paternal limit setting. The centrality of this concern is well known to both of us in the analytic work.

While Dr. B is in Singapore, his wife calls him to tell him of her concerns about SARS and to advise him to wear a surgical mask. He feels oddly furious with her as a result, although aware on some level that she means to be helpful. He has the thought that she has spoiled everything. When masks are indeed distributed both at his hotel and at the airport, his panic increases. He feels that he cannot breathe and then that the whole undertaking is folly anyway, as he and everyone else at the meeting will surely die an excruciating respiratory death. His anger is so great that he does not answer his wife's subsequent calls, and in addition, develops trouble using his legs at the airport-trouble that compromises his proceeding through security and occasions an unpleasant interview with the airport authorities.

Upon his return, Dr. B and I are able to understand together that the mask evokes imagery and frozen metaphor about his parents' Holocaust past, particularly his mother's experience of being taken to a gas chamber at Auschwitz and then marched out again when the machinery failed and therefore could not kill her. Gone is his playful interest in caning in Singapore-or, more accurately, it has been pushed aside by his panic, resulting from an intrusion into the process and into his entire being of an issue around which he cannot play.

Dr. B describes the ways in which his panic interfered with his capacity to think in Singapore, and his belief that, without the Ativan he had brought with him, he would never have been able to leave the country. Importantly, the Ativan was prescribed by a family physician, also a member of the survivor community and therefore completely trustworthy. Once home, with charac-teristic defensive and adaptive brilliance, the patient turns his thoughts to designing a truly effective gas mask through which coronavirus-sized particles cannot pass. Dr. B associates from his passing through airport security to his mother's entering the gas chamber. He angrily notes that there was no man there to help him. He makes a number of references that I understand to denote my absence and uselessness to him in a moment of great indisposition and helplessness.

In the analysis, we continue to struggle with Dr. B's own arrested killing interests and his persistent belief that I am a Nazi. His attacks on me in this regard are less costly than his attacks on his wife. (Although the attacks on me make it hard for him to trust my observations-and absolutely impossible, for instance, for him to take Ativan that I would prescribe. He says that, were I to recommend a medication, he would be well advised not to take it. I have not suggested that he should take any.) And so we make steady, albeit very slow, progress in recognizing what he calls his "brain state," which confounds the historical past with the here-and-now present. Dr. B is able to recognize that he has had an experience of conflating past and present in Singapore, and that this has affected his capacity to think with his customary creativity and playfulness. He can acknowledge that he and I have learned a lot about this form of indisposition. He cannot, however, free himself from the thought that his wife intended to increase his anxiety, or that I should have been able to protect him from this experience. He states that I "hung him out to dry." Generally, he feels that he and I think well together, but that we really do not get the work done. * * * * * * * * Dr. B's history was remarkable for the fact that his survivor father was completely devastated by his wartime experiences, and in fact perished when his son was five years old. His memories of his father are of a man who was crushed and who could not manage any more. Mostly, he stayed in bed, presided over by his wife who took care of everything. Dr. B always prided himself on his own capacity to manage, and this he did with extraordinary, even driven, brilliance. He came to see me after he was not awarded a Nobel prize that everyone felt to have been his due. His response was to feel crushed and as though he could not get up from bed. Long-smoldering resentments toward his wife now seemed unmanageable, and he felt that he might lose everything.

In our work, which has been stormy in Dr. B's experience, we have tried to understand more about his extraordinary achievements and his feeling of massive derailment. We have found ourselves repeatedly in the realm of (a) present and absent fathers, and (b) indispensable and admirable, but strangely preoccupied and unavailable, mothers. Over time, we have come to learn together how Dr. B could roll with the punches, but then he would "turn to jelly, as if my skeletal system decomposed," and would no longer be able to function. Our focus has been to understand this decomposition of what allows him to remain upright.

Recently, we have encountered a fantasy that his mother might have had a Nazi lover at Auschwitz, and that said lover might have disabled the gas chamber when his mother entered it. Dr. B wonders if the gas chamber disabler might have been a member of my family. When he thinks such thoughts, the state of turning to jelly overwhelms him. He even feels that he needs to stop using the couch for fear that he will not be able to stand up from it, once in the throes of this brain/body state in which his very thought processes turn to a different state of matter.

While being open to Dr. B's using the couch or not as he sees fit and finds most useful, I have found myself wondering what would happen if I were to oppose this postural change. I ponder the meaning of this self-inquiry by an analyst who is asked to become a more complex Nazi, and who now even feels that way. I know that I hover in the realm between a good enough father who might set and enforce limits and a compli-cated Nazi who might both herd his female prisoner into a gas chamber and disable it at the same time.

* * * * * * * * Dr. B uses different mechanisms from Nurit's. He does not elaborate obsessive-compulsive symptoms, but rather develops a panicked state and experiences a radical, psychosomatic, "osteoporotic" collapse. The intrusion upon a fluid and dynamic capacity to recontextualize and recategorize memory is the same, however. The conflation of past and present freezes the metaphoric process and substitutes metonymy for full-deck play capacity (Herzog and O'Connell, unpublished) . In the analysis, all these deformations of the play process declare themselves.

As Ms. Kogan needed to do with Nurit, I find myself pondering about the ways in which I am conducting the analysis and looking for collusive aspects of a mutually shared constriction of the metaphoric process that may be deforming our play. Am I less willing to be the Nazi than the play requires? Am I a couched or couching, impotent and thus abandoning, father? Am I more interested in the turning to jelly than in the omnipresence of murder, seduction, and compromise? How are we to access all Dr. B's representations of self with mother, self with father, and self with mother and father together-in other words, all his potential triadic realities-unless the aggressive, ambivalent Nazi/father/analyst enters the spielraum? Does my patient feel "hung out to dry" when diverted from his interest in corporal punishment as a part of the judicial system in Singapore by the imposition of the very real threat of respiratory collapse? Must our play engage both of these threats and "final" or penultimate solutions in order to allow his play function to thaw, thus becoming fully utilizable by him even under circumstances that are inherently stressful?

Observe that the trajectory from fantasy about a disciplining father to that of an annihilating Nazi is steep and perilous. Dr. B struggles to find a way to acknowledge what he lacks and still retain his sense of historical and present-day self. * * * * * * * * Deep play is a concept that Jeremy Bentham elaborates in his Theory of Legislation (1964) . By this, he means play in which the stakes are so high that it is, from his utilitarian point of view, irrational for anyone to engage in it at all. Anthropologist Clifford Geertz (1973) expands this concept to describe a Balinese cockfight and the way in which what happens in such a culturally sanctioned event allows a society to imagine and to feel tumultuous internal and interactive themata that are otherwise unavailable.

I use the concept of deep play to convey something about what transpires in the analytic situation when both analysand and analyst risk, are able to risk, are compelled to risk, in order to more fully understand-and by so doing, attempt to gain not only greater clarity regarding past traumata, but also some opportunity to effect mimetic mobility, to alter the inscape and allow development to proceed. I have previously tried to think about these notions in my papers on play modes, where I have spoken about the shift from displacement to enactment to interactive enactment, and in my work on intrapsychic reconfiguration.

As I think about being or even resembling the complex Nazi with Dr. B, or perhaps the minister of justice from Singapore, I think I wrestle with a dilemma similar to what Ms. Kogan describes in her work with Nurit. In some ways, the analyst is asked to participate in an interactive enactment, and in others, to move beyond the more comfortable forms of accompanying and engaging with his or her analysand. Our patients are, of course, struggling with all this and more.

Ownership of both the feeling of having been grievously assaulted, whether through transmitted trauma or by more direct abuse, and the resultant rage at both the assailant and at all of those who failed to provide adequate protection requires an extant internal template of self with others, which, in the massively traumatized individual, has been partially or totally ablated. My son Noah Herzog and 1 (Herzog 1997) have hypothesized that post-traumatic ablation of the self-other internal representational world results in the subsequent construction of an exoskeleton of self-structure. We use this term because such self-structure remains interactively contingent and cannot be fully internalized. Continuous efforts to reach the other and an absolute requirement for adequate reciprocation are mandatory.

We have suggested that the poet Paul Celarr's phrase. "a desperate dialogue to a receptive you" (1972, p. 17) , is an extraordinarily precise way of detailing this adaptation. Furthermore, we have hypothesized that Celan's suicide, as well as Primo Levi's and Jerzsy Kozincki's, reflects the dilemma of the creative artist who, following massive trauma, establishes a creatively "desperate dialogue with a receptive you"-the audience-and then cannot survive when the audience turns away or loses interest. When the analyst enters into such an interactive enactment with the massively traumatized patient, a promise is made: "I shall not extract myself knowingly. 1 shall fight with you and for you in the modality that your pain requires until the battle is won-until you have reclaimed your own modulated aggression and can fight on your own and tell me that 1 am no longer a required comrade in arms."

Dr. B's use of the metaphor of skeletal dissolution is particularly interesting in this regard. He needs me to strengthen his psychic osteoblasts and to inhibit his psychic osteoclasts until he resumes these functions. He needs to restore his metaphoric capacity to full-deck functioning, thus keeping his bone structure and not turning into a bowl of jelly. Ms. Kogan entered into such a successful play encounter with Nurit, and Nurit emerged better able to love, work, and play. This is not only good analysis, but a profound example of how the very good analyst helps the analysand return to playing with a full deck.
